sen.j: 源氏（げんじ、みなもとうじ）は、「源」を氏・姓（本姓）とする一族である。
sen.e: Genji clan or Minamoto clan is a family whose honorary surname is Minamoto.
Genji clan or Minamoto clan is a family whose honorary surname was Minamoto.
The Minamoto clan (Genji) is a family whose honorary surname was Minamoto.
sen.cmt: Genji clan or Minamoto clan→The Minamoto clan (Genji)としました。

sen.j: 日本においては皇族が臣籍降下する際に名乗る氏の一つであった。
sen.e: In Japan, Genji was one of the surnames that an imperial family took when it was demoted to an ministry.
In Japan, Genji was one of the surnames that an imperial family took when it was demoted to an ministry.
In Japan, Minamoto was one of the surnames that an imperial family took when it was demoted to an ministry.

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）は朝臣。
sen.e: Its Kabane, hereditary title, is Ason.
Its Kabane, hereditary title, is Ason.
Its Kabane, hereditary title, is Ason.

sen.j: もっとも有名なものは、幕府を開き征夷大将軍の家柄となった清和源氏であるが、家格が最も高いのは村上源氏であるとされる。
sen.e: The most famous branch family of the Genji clan was the Seiwa Genji, whereas the noblest was the Murakami Genji.
The most famous branch family of the Genji clan was the Seiwa Genji, whereas the noblest was the Murakami Genji.

The most famous branch family of the Minamoto clan was the Seiwa-Genji who established Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and became Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), whereas the noblest was the Murakami-Genji.
sen.cmt: 「幕府を開き征夷大将軍の家柄となった」を訳出、the Genji clan→the Minamoto clanに修正、Seiwa-Genji、Murakami-Genjiとし、余分なスペース消去

sen.j: 流派はこのほか多数ある。
sen.e: There are many other branch families.
There are many other branch families.
There are many other branch families.

sen.j: 源姓（本姓が源氏）の家系はそれぞれ別の苗字を号しているため、現在「源」を今日的な意味の姓として名乗る例はそれほど多くなく、推定人口は4,000人程である。
sen.e: Nowadays, there are not so many people, approximately 4000 according to an estimation, who carry Genji as relevant surname, because the families of the Genji clan (whose hereditary title is Genji) have their own family names.

Nowadays, there are not so many people, approximately 4000 according to an estimation, who carry Genji as their surname, because the families of the Genji clan (whose hereditary title is Genji) have their own family names.

Nowadays, there are not so many people, approximately 4000 according to an estimation, who carry Minamoto as their surname, because the families of the Minamoto clan (whose hereditary title is Minamoto) have their own family names.
sen.cmt: Genji→Minamoto、the Genji clan→the Minamoto clanに修正、余分なスペース消去

sen.j: しかし、源義忠流清和源氏（源義高 (左兵衛権佐)・源義清 (左京権大夫)及び源義雄の子孫、河内源氏）は現在も、源を今日的な意味の姓としており、江戸時代の資料等にも苗字・姓とも源となっている。
sen.e: However, the Seiwa Genji of MINAMOTO no Yoshitada's line (the descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshitaka (Sahyoegonza), MINAMOTO no Yoshikiyo (Sakyogonnodaibu) and Kawachi Genji, the descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshikatsu) carry Genji as relevant surname and the documents published in the Edo period tell that both their surname and hereditary title were Minamoto.

However, the Seiwa Genji of MINAMOTO no Yoshitada's line (the descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshitaka (Sahyoegonza), MINAMOTO no Yoshikiyo (Sakyogonnodaibu) and Kawachi Genji, the descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshikatsu) carry Genji as thier surname and the documents published in the Edo period say that both their surname and hereditary title were Minamoto.

However, the Seiwa-Genji of MINAMOTO no Yoshitada's line (the descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshitaka (Sahyoegonza), MINAMOTO no Yoshikiyo (Sakyogonnodaibu) and Kawachi-Genji, the descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshikatsu) carry Genji as thier surname and the documents published in the Edo period say that both their surname and hereditary title were Minamoto.

sen.j: 著名な源姓の人物に関しては、源氏の人物一覧を参照。
sen.e: For famous persons of the Genji clan, see the list of the Genji clan persons.
For famous persons of the Genji clan, see the list of the Genji clan persons.
For famous persons of the Minamoto clan, see the list of the Minamoto clan persons.
sen.cmt: the Genji clan→the Minamoto clanに修正

sen.j: 源氏は源の姓を持つ氏族であるが、嵯峨天皇が生まれた子らにその姓を与え、皇室と祖を同じくするという名誉の意味をこめて与えた。
sen.e: Genji, which refers to a clan who carries Minamoto as surname, was given by the Emperor Saga to his children to give them a honor of being originated from the Imperial House.
Genji, which refers to a clan who carries Minamoto as surname, was given by the Emperor Saga to his children to honor their having originated from the Imperial House.
The Minamoto clan, which refers to a clan who carries Minamoto as surname, was given by the Emperor Saga to his children to honor their having originated from the Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: Genji→The Minamoto clanに修正、the Imperial House→the Imperial Familyとしました。

sen.j: 嵯峨天皇に皇子皇女が増え、朝廷の財政を逼迫させる基にもなることから、早くに臣籍降下することが皇胤にとって子孫繁栄の道であった。
sen.e: Since the increase in the number of the Emperor Saga's princes and princesses might have caused Imperial court's fiscal tightness, it was a better way for the Emperor's bloodlines to allow these princes and princesses to become early his subject in order to ensure the prosperity of his descendants.

Since the increase in the number of the Emperor Saga's princes and princesses might have caused the Imperial court's fiscal tightness, it was a better way for the Emperor's bloodlines to allow these princes and princesses to become his subject earlier in order to ensure the prosperity of his descendants.

Since the increase in the number of the Emperor Saga's princes and princesses might have caused the Imperial court's fiscal tightness, it was a better way for the Emperor's bloodlines to allow these princes and princesses to become his subject earlier in order to ensure the prosperity of his descendants.

sen.j: 親王ながら、皇位を望めない場合や、諸王にあって親王宣下を望めない皇族が自ら降下を求める場合と、朝廷から一方的に降下させる場合とがあり皇別氏族を取り巻く状況は朝廷の財政事情と常に連動する要素が強かった。
sen.e: There were the cases in which even princes could not want to become emperor, in which the imperial families who had no chance to be a prince or princess asked him by themselves to allow them to become his subject or in which the Imperial court asked them unilaterally to be his subject, thus the environment surrounding the clans separated from the Imperial household were always linked with financial situation of the Imperial court.

There were cases in which even princes did not want to become emperor, in which the imperial families who had no chance to be a prince or princess asked him themselves to allow them to become his subject or in which the Imperial court asked them unilaterally to be his subject, thus the environment surrounding the clans separated from the Imperial household were always linked with the financial situation of the Imperial court.

There were cases in which even princes did not want to become emperor, in which the imperial families who had no chance to be a prince or princess asked him themselves to allow them to become his subject or in which the Imperial court asked them unilaterally to be his subject, thus the environment surrounding the clans separated from the Imperial household were always linked with the financial situation of the Imperial court.

sen.j: 嵯峨天皇の後の天皇も度々皇族を源氏として臣籍に下したことから、嵯峨天皇を祖とする源氏を嵯峨源氏と称する様になり、以後源氏はそれぞれの祖と仰ぐ天皇の号をもって氏族の称とした（仁明源氏、文徳源氏、清和源氏、宇多源氏など）。
sen.e: Some of other emperors after the Emperor Saga also demoted their family members to their subjects by giving them the surname of Minamoto and those Genji who were descended from the Emperor Saga called themselves Saga Genji and afterwards, Genji took their parental emperors' names as their clan's surnames (such as Ninmyou Genji, Montoku Genji, Seiwa Genji and Uda Genji)

Some of the other emperors after the Emperor Saga also demoted their family members to being their subjects by giving them the surname of Minamoto and those Genji who were descended from the Emperor Saga called themselves Saga Genji and afterwards, Genji took their parental emperors' names as their clan's surnames (such as Ninmyou Genji, Montoku Genji, Seiwa Genji and Uda Genji)

Some of the other emperors after the Emperor Saga also demoted their family members to being their subjects by giving them the surname of Minamoto and those Minamoto clan who were descended from the Emperor Saga called themselves Saga-Genji and afterwards, the Minamoto clan took their parental emperors' names as their clan's surnames (such as Ninmyo-Genji, Montoku-Genji, Seiwa-Genji and Uda-Genji).
sen.cmt: Genji→Minamoto clanとし、Saga-Genji, Ninmyo-Genji, Montoku-Genji, Seiwa-Genji, Uda-Genjiに修正、ピリオド追加

sen.j: また、朝廷が皇族を臣籍降下させ源氏とした背景としては、上級貴族として皇室の藩塀とすることという理由もあったが、実際には3代目以降も上級貴族であり続けた例はほとんどなく、大半は受領階級として地方へ赴任しそこで土着して武士化するか、中央で中下級貴族として細々と生き延びた。
sen.e: Although one of the aims of the Imperial court's demotion of their family members to their subjects by giving them the surname of Minamoto was to allow them to be the subsidiary of the Imperial Family as the upper class nobles, in fact only few of them kept their status for more than three generations, while many others took regional posts as middle classes and later became samurai, or earned a sparse living as middle and lower classes in the center.

Although one of the aims of the Imperial court's demotion of their family members to their subjects by giving them the surname of Minamoto was to allow them to be the subsidiary of the Imperial Family as upper class nobles, in fact only a few of them kept their status for more than three generations, while many others took regional posts as middle classes and later became samurai, or earned a sparse living as middle and lower classes in the center.

Although one of the aims of the Imperial court's demotion of their family members to their subjects by giving them the surname of Minamoto was to allow them to be the subsidiary of the Imperial Family as upper class nobles, in fact only a few of them kept their status for more than three generations, while many others took regional posts as middle classes and later became samurai, or earned a sparse living as middle and lower classes in the center.

sen.j: 他に、皇族に対して賜った姓としては、他に在原氏、平氏などがある。
sen.e: Other surnames given to imperial families include Ariwara, Taira etc.
Other surnames given to imperial families include Ariwara, Taira etc.
Other surnames given to imperial families include Ariwara, Taira etc.

sen.j: また、代表的な家紋である「笹竜胆」は北条氏の家紋である三角形が並んでいる「三つ鱗」より古く、日本最古の家紋であると言われている。
sen.e: Its most representative family crest "Sasarindo" is older than "Mitsuuroko" of the Hojo clan, which contains triangles, and is said to be the oldest in Japan.
Its most representative family crest "Sasarindo" is older than "Mitsuuroko" of the Hojo clan, which contains triangles, and is said to be the oldest in Japan.

Its most representative Kamon (family crest) 'Sasarindo' (bamboo grass and gentians) is older than 'Mitsuuroko' (three scales in a circle) of the Hojo clan, which contains triangles, and is said to be the oldest in Japan.
sen.cmt: Sasarindo、Mitsuurokoの補足追加、シングルクォーテーションに変更family crest→Kamon (family crest)に変更

tit.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 清和源氏は、二十一流あるといわれる源氏における一家系であるが、武家源氏として歴史上に名を馳せたことにより、清和源氏をして源氏と称することが多い。
sen.e: The Seiwa Genji is one of the so-called 21 branch families of the Minamoto clan and it is often considered to be the mainstream of the Minamoto clan due to its achievement in historical fame as military Genji.
The Seiwa Genji is one of the so-called 21 branch families of the Minamoto clan and it is often considered to be the mainstream of the Minamoto clan due to its historical fame as military Genji.
The Seiwa-Genji is one of the so-called 21 branch families of the Minamoto clan and it is often considered to be the mainstream of the Minamoto clan due to its historical fame as military Genji.

sen.j: この一族は清和天皇の皇子を祖とする。
sen.e: This family is descended from the princes of the Emperor Seiwa.
This family is descended from the princes of the Emperor Seiwa.
This family is descended from the princes of the Emperor Seiwa.

sen.j: 武家源氏として名を馳せた清和源氏においては畿内に始まり各地に土着しており、源満仲の子から摂津源氏、大和源氏、河内源氏とに分かれ、河内国を本拠地とした河内源氏の源義家（八幡太郎義家）はその主流で、その子孫は鎌倉幕府を開いた源頼朝に代表される武士として栄え、さらに河内源氏からは石川源氏、甲斐源氏、常陸源氏、下野源氏（足利氏）、上野源氏（新田氏）などが分派している。
sen.e: Seiwa Genji, who enjoyed its fame as military Genji, originated in Kinai, or current Kansai region, spread to various regions, and then split up into Settu Genji, Yamato Genji and Kawachi Genji after MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, and MINAMOTO no Yoshiie (Taro Yoshiie HACHIMAN) of the Kawachi Genji, who were based in Kawachi Province, was the mainstream of them, whose descendants flourished as samurai represented by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who established Kamakura Shogunate, and other clans such as Ishikawa Genji, Kai Genji, Hitachi Genji, Shimotsuke Genji (Ashikaga clan) and Kozuke Genji (Nitta clan) were descended from Kawachi Genji as well.

Seiwa Genji, who enjoyed its fame as military Genji, originated in Kinai, or current Kansai region, spread to various regions, and then split up into Settu Genji, Yamato Genji and Kawachi Genji after MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, and MINAMOTO no Yoshiie (Taro Yoshiie HACHIMAN) of the Kawachi Genji, who were based in Kawachi Province, was the mainstream of them, whose descendants flourished as samurai represented by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who established Kamakura Shogunate, and other clans such as Ishikawa Genji, Kai Genji, Hitachi Genji, Shimotsuke Genji (Ashikaga clan) and Kozuke Genji (Nitta clan) were descended from Kawachi Genji as well.

Seiwa-Genji, who enjoyed its fame as military Genji, originated in Kinai, or current Kansai region, spread to various regions, and then split up into Settu-Genji, Yamato-Genji and Kawachi-Genji after MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, and MINAMOTO no Yoshiie (Taro Yoshiie HACHIMAN) of the Kawachi-Genji, who were based in Kawachi Province, was the mainstream of them, whose descendants flourished as samurai represented by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who established the Kamakura bakufu, and other clans such as Ishikawa-Genji, Kai-Genji, Hitachi-Genji, Shimotsuke-Genji (Ashikaga clan) and Kozuke-Genji (Nitta clan) were descended from Kawachi-Genji as well.
sen.cmt: ○○源氏→○○-Genjiの表記に統一、Kamakura Shogunate→the Kamakura bakufuに修正

sen.j: 摂津国を本拠地とした摂津源氏からは多田源氏、美濃源氏その他が分派しており、いずれも清和源氏一門であり、いわゆる「武家源氏」である。
sen.e: Tada Genji, Mino Genji and others were descended from Settu Province-based Settsu Genji and they were a branch of Seiwa Genji and so-called "military Genji".
Tada Genji, Mino Genji and others were descended from Settu Province-based Settsu Genji and they were a branch of Seiwa Genji and the so-called "military Genji".
Tada-Genji, Mino-Genji and others were descended from Settu Province-based Settsu-Genji and they were a branch of Seiwa-Genji and the so-called 'military Genji.'
sen.cmt: ○○源氏→○○-Genjiの表記に統一、シングルクォーテーションに変更、ピリオドの位置を移動

sen.j: 清和源氏以外に武家となった源氏としては、嵯峨源氏の源融を祖とする「融流嵯峨源氏」があり、嵯峨源氏の武家として系譜を伝えた代表は、摂津国を基盤とした渡辺氏とその分流の松浦氏であり、また宇多源氏の中で武家として近江国を基盤とした系統は近江源氏（佐佐木源氏）と称し、佐々木氏として有力武士団に成長していく。
sen.e: Another example of military Genji than Seiwa Genji is "Toru-ryu Saga Genji" who originated from MINAMOTO no Toru of the Saga Genji, and those who represented the clan as the worriers of Saga Genji includes Settu Province-based Watanabe clan and its branch Matsuura clan, and also those among Uda Genji who were based in Omi Province were called Omi Genji (Sasaki Genji) and grew up to be the samurai group as the Sasaki clan.

Another example of military Genji compared to Seiwa Genji is "Toru-ryu Saga Genji" who originated from MINAMOTO no Toru of the Saga Genji, and those who represented the clan as the warriors of Saga Genji include Settu Province-based Watanabe clan and its branch Matsuura clan, and also those among Uda Genji who were based in Omi Province were called Omi Genji (Sasaki Genji) and grew up to be the powerful samurai group known as the Sasaki clan.

Another example of military Genji compared to Seiwa-Genji is 'Toru-ryu Saga-Genji' who originated from MINAMOTO no Toru of the Saga-Genji, and those who represented the clan as the warriors of Saga-Genji include Settu Province-based Watanabe clan and its branch Matsuura clan, and also those among Uda-Genji who were based in Omi Province were called Omi-Genji (Sasaki-Genji) and grew up to be the powerful samurai group known as the Sasaki clan.
sen.cmt: ○○源氏→○○-Genjiの表記に統一、シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 中央貴族として栄えた源氏として村上天皇の皇子を祖とする村上源氏がある。
sen.e: An example of Genji who gained power as the central nobles is Murakami Genji, who was descended from the princes of Emperor Murakami.
An example of a Genji who gained power as central noble is Murakami Genji, who was descended from the princes of Emperor Murakami.
An example of a Minamoto clan who gained power as central noble is Murakami-Genji, who was descended from the princes of Emperor Murakami.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、Genji→Minamoto clanに修正

sen.j: 同じ源氏でも公卿として繁栄する系統や、武士や神官となる系統に別れるのは、政治情勢や臣籍降下する者、母方の勢力や身分がその後の官途に大きく左右する為である。
sen.e: The reason why some Genji clan flourished as nobles while others became samurai and Shinto priests is because their positions were largely dependent on the political situation, who demoted them and their maternal classes and influences.

The reason why some Genji clan flourished as nobles while others became samurai and Shinto priests is because their positions were largely dependent on the political situation, who demoted them and their maternal classes and influences.

The reason why some Minamoto clan flourished as nobles while others became samurai and Shinto priests is because their positions were largely dependent on the political situation, who demoted them and their maternal classes and influences.

sen.j: 特に天皇の皇子が降下することを、「一世の源氏」といい、任官の上で大いに優遇された。
sen.e: Especially, the demotion of the sons of the emperors was called "Issei no Genji" (Genji of the first generation) and they were given preferential treatment in regard to their position.
Especially, the demotion of the sons of the emperors was called "Issei no Genji" (Genji of the first generation) and they were given preferential treatment in regard to their position.
Especially, the demotion of the sons of the emperors was called 'Issei no Genji' (Minamoto clan of the first generation) and they were given preferential treatment in regard to their position.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、Issei no Genjiの補足一部修正

sen.j: 皇孫に至って臣籍降下することを「二世の源氏」といい、一世の源氏よりも家系的には不利を蒙った。
sen.e: The demotion of the grandsons of the emperors was called "Nisei no Genji" (Genji of the second generation) and they had disadvantages against Issei no Genji.
The demotion of the grandsons of the emperors was called "Nisei no Genji" (Genji of the second generation) and they had disadvantages against Issei no Genji.
The demotion of the grandsons of the emperors was called 'Nisei no Genji' (Minamoto clan of the second generation) and they had disadvantages against Issei no Genji.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、Nisei no Genjiの補足一部修正

sen.j: 平安時代後期以降、皇位継承とは関わりのない皇子皇女たちは出家する慣例が生まれたため、賜姓源氏はほとんど途絶えていたが、江戸時代に入って一家が生まれた（広幡家）。
sen.e: Since the late Heian period, when it became a custom for the princes and princesses who were unrelated to the succession to become priests, Genji who were direct descendant of the Imperial Family were almost extinct, although a new family (Hirohata family) came out in the Edo period.

Since the late Heian period, when it became customary for the princes and princesses who were unrelated to the succession to become priests, Genji who were direct descendant of the Imperial Family almost became extinct, although a new family (Hirohata family) came out in the Edo period.

Since the late Heian period, when it became customary for the princes and princesses who were unrelated to the succession to become priests, the Minamoto clan who were direct descendant of the Imperial Family almost became extinct, although a new family (Hirohata family) came out in the Edo period.

sen.j: 嵯峨天皇以来、21代の天皇の子孫に源氏が与えられたと言われている（源氏を与えられた当人やその子の代で断絶・消滅した家も含めて）。
sen.e: It is said that the descendants of 21 emperors were given the surnames of Minamoto since the Emperor Saga (including the families which became extinct in the generations of the people who were given the surname themselves and in their children's generations).

It is said that the descendants of 21 emperors were given the surnames of Minamoto since the Emperor Saga (including the families which became extinct in the generations of the people who were given the surname themselves and in their children's generations).

It is said that the descendants of 21 emperors were given the surnames of Minamoto since the Emperor Saga (including the families which became extinct in the generations of the people who were given the surname themselves and in their children's generations).

tit.e: Main branch families of the Genji clan
Main branch families of the Genji clan
Main Branch Families of the Minamoto Clan
tit.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更、Genji clan→Minamto Clanに修正

sen.j: 52代嵯峨天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifty-second Emperor Saga.
Descendants of the fifty-second Emperor Saga.
Descendants of the fifty-second Emperor Saga.

sen.j: 嵯峨天皇は多くの皇子皇女に源氏姓を賜り臣籍降下させた。
sen.e: The Emperor Saga demoted a number of his princes and princesses by giving them the surname of Minamoto.
The Emperor Saga demoted a number of his princes and princesses by giving them the surname of Minamoto.
The Emperor Saga demoted a number of his princes and princesses by giving them the surname of Minamoto.

sen.j: この内、源信 (公卿)・源常・源融は左大臣となり、平安時代初期に朝廷の一大勢力をなした。
sen.e: Among them, MINAMOTO no Makoto (noble), MINAMOTO no Tokiwa and MINAMOTO no Toru became Sadaijin, Minister of the Left and formed a big power of the Imperial court at the beginning of the Heian period.

Among them, MINAMOTO no Makoto (noble), MINAMOTO no Tokiwa and MINAMOTO no Toru became Sadaijin, Minister of the Left and formed a big power of the Imperial court at the beginning of the Heian period.

Among them, MINAMOTO no Makoto (noble), MINAMOTO no Tokiwa and MINAMOTO no Toru became Sadaijin, Minister of the Left and formed a big power of the Imperial court at the beginning of the Heian period.

sen.j: また、源融の系統は地方に土着として武家となった。
sen.e: The lineage of MINAMOTO no Toru became a local family of worriers.
The lineage of MINAMOTO no Toru became a local family of warriors..
The lineage of MINAMOTO no Toru became a local family of warriors..

sen.j: 子孫に渡辺氏、蒲池氏など。
sen.e: Its descendants include the Watanabe clan, the Hasuike clan etc.
Its descendants include the Watanabe clan, the Hasuike clan etc.
Its descendants include the Watanabe clan, the Hasuike clan etc.

sen.j: 54代仁明天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifty-fourth Emperor Ninmyo
Descendants of the fifty-fourth Emperor Ninmyo
Descendants of the fifty-fourth Emperor Ninmyo.

sen.j: 仁明天皇の子、源多・源光 (公卿)は右大臣となった。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Masaru and MINAMOTO no Hikaru (court nobles), children of the Emperor Ninmyo, became Udaijin, Minister of the Right.
MINAMOTO no Masaru and MINAMOTO no Hikaru (court nobles), children of the Emperor Ninmyo, became Udaijin, Minister of the Right.
MINAMOTO no Masaru and MINAMOTO no Hikaru (court nobles), children of the Emperor Ninmyo, became Udaijin, Minister of the Right.

sen.j: また、源光の子孫に、清和源氏の源満仲の妻の父であり、嵯峨源氏の源綱（渡辺綱）の養父である源敦がいる。
sen.e: In addition, one of descendants of MINAMOTO no Hikaru was MINAMOTO no Atsushi, the father of the wife of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka of Seiwa Genji and also foster father of MINAMOTO no Tsuna (WATANABE no Tsuna) of Saga Genji.

In addition, among the descendants of MINAMOTO no Hikaru was MINAMOTO no Atsushi are the father of the wife of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka of Seiwa Genji and also foster father of MINAMOTO no Tsuna (WATANABE no Tsuna) of Saga Genji.

In addition, among the descendants of MINAMOTO no Hikaru was MINAMOTO no Atsushi, who was the father of the wife of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka of Seiwa-Genji and also foster father of MINAMOTO no Tsuna (WATANABE no Tsuna) of Saga-Genji.
sen.cmt: are→, who wasに修正、Seiwa-Genji、Saga-Genjiとしました。

sen.j: 55代文徳天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifty-fifth Emperor Buntoku.
Descendants of the fifty-fifth Emperor Buntoku.
Descendants of the fifty-fifth Emperor Montoku.

sen.j: 左大臣となった源能有の子孫に北面武士となった坂戸氏がある。
sen.e: Descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshiaki who was Sadaijin (the Minster of the Left) included Sakado who became Hokumen no bushi (north front worrier).
Descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshiaki who was Sadaijin (the Minster of the Left) included Sakado who became Hokumen no bushi (north front worrier).
Descendants of MINAMOTO no Yoshiaki who was Sadaijin included the Sakado clan who became Hokumen no bushi (north front worrier).
sen.cmt: Sadaijin→既出のため補足削除、Sakado→the Sakado clanとしました。

sen.j: 56代清和天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifty-sixth Emperor Seiwa.
Descendants of the fifty-sixth Emperor Seiwa.
Descendants of the fifty-sixth Emperor Seiwa.

sen.j: もっとも栄えたのは第六皇子貞純親王の子・源経基の系統。
sen.e: Their most prosperous lineage was the prince MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the child of MINAMOTO no Sadazumi who was the sixth prince.
Their most prosperous lineage was the prince MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the child of MINAMOTO no Sadazumi who was the sixth prince.
Their most prosperous lineage was the prince MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, the child of MINAMOTO no Sadazumi who was the sixth prince.

sen.j: 鎌倉将軍一覧を輩出したことから、武家の統領の家柄とされ、足利氏・徳川氏の両将軍家を初めとして、極めて多数の武家が清和源氏の子孫と称した。
sen.e: Seiwa Genji was considered to be the top of the military families because it produced successive shogun during the Kamakura period, an extremely large number of military families, such as Ashikaga and Tokugawa who produced samurai, claimed descendants of Seiwa Genji.

Seiwa Genji was considered to be the top of the military families because it produced successive shogun during the Kamakura period, an extremely large number of military families, such as Ashikaga and Tokugawa who produced samurai, and claimed to be descendants of Seiwa Genji.

Seiwa-Genji was considered to be the top of the military families because it produced successive shogun during the Kamakura period, an extremely large number of military families, such as Ashikaga and Tokugawa who produced samurai, and claimed to be descendants of Seiwa-Genji.

sen.j: 57代陽成天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifty-seventh Emperor Yosei.
Descendants of the fifty-seventh Emperor Yosei.
Descendants of the fifty-seventh Emperor Yozei.

sen.j: 清和源氏の祖とされる源経基は陽成天皇の孫とする説があり、この説に賛意を示す学者もいるが、広く学界の承認するまでには至っていない。
sen.e: There is an explanation that MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, origin of Seiwa Genji, was a grandchild of the Emperor Yosei, which is sympathized by some researchers, although it is not widely approved by academy.
There is an explanation that MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, origin of Seiwa Genji, was a grandchild of the Emperor Yosei, which accepted by some researchers, although it is not widely approved by academy.
There is an explanation that MINAMOTO no Tsunemoto, origin of Seiwa-Genji, was a grandchild of the Emperor Yozei, which accepted by some researchers, although it is not widely approved by academy.

sen.j: （参照→貞純親王）
sen.e: (See Princess Sadazumi.)
(See Princess Sadazumi.)
(See Imperial Prince Sadazumi.)

sen.j: 58代光孝天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifty-eighth Emperor Koko.
Descendants of the fifty-eighth Emperor Koko.
Descendants of the fifty-eighth Emperor Koko.

sen.j: 第一皇子である是忠親王の曾孫源康尚は仏師流の祖となり、この系統から仏工の各流派を輩出した。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yasunao, a great-grandchild of the first princess Koretada, was a patriarch of sculptors of Buddha statues, from which each school of Buddha statue sculpture originated.
MINAMOTO no Yasunao, a great-grandchild of the first princess Koretada, was a patriarch of sculptors of Buddha statues, from which each school of Buddha statue sculpture originated.
MINAMOTO no Yasunao, a great-grandchild of the first princess Koretada, was a patriarch of sculptors of Buddha statues, from which each school of Buddha statue sculpture originated.

sen.j: 59代宇多天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifty-ninth Emperor Uda.
Descendants of the fifty-ninth Emperor Uda.
Descendants of the fifty-ninth Emperor Uda.

sen.j: 第八皇子である敦実親王の子、源雅信・源重信兄弟はいずれも左大臣となった。
sen.e: Both of the brothers MINAMOTO no Masanobu and MINAMOTO no Shigehartu, the children of the eighth Prince Astuzane, became Sadaijin.
Both of the brothers MINAMOTO no Masanobu and MINAMOTO no Shigehartu, the children of the eighth Prince Astuzane, became Sadaijin.
Both of the brothers MINAMOTO no Masanobu and MINAMOTO no Shigehartu, the children of the eighth Prince Atsuzane, became Sadaijin.

sen.j: 特に源雅信の子孫が栄え、公家としては堂上家5家を、武家として佐々木氏を輩出した。
sen.e: The descendants of MINAMOTO no Masanobu were prosperous among others, producing five Tosho family lineages as court nobles and Sasaki clan as a military family.
The descendants of MINAMOTO no Masanobu were prosperous among others, producing five Tosho family lineages as court nobles and Sasaki clan as a military family.

The descendants of MINAMOTO no Masanobu were prosperous among others, producing five Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) lineages as court nobles and Sasaki clan as a military family.

sen.j: 60代醍醐天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the sixtieth Emperor Daigo.
Descendants of the sixtieth Emperor Daigo.
Descendants of the sixtieth Emperor Daigo.

sen.j: 第十皇子の源高明は左大臣となったが後に安和の変にて失脚した。
sen.e: His tenth prince MINAMOTO no Takaakira became Sadaijin, but fell from power in the Anwa incident.
His tenth prince MINAMOTO no Takaakira became Sadaijin, but fell from power in the Anwa incident.
His tenth prince MINAMOTO no Takaakira became Sadaijin, but fell from power in the Anwa incident.

sen.j: 源高明の子孫に岡本氏・河尻氏がある。
sen.e: The descendants of MINAMOTO no Takaakira include Okamoto and Ejiri.
The descendants of MINAMOTO no Takaakira include Okamoto and Ejiri.
The descendants of MINAMOTO no Takaakira include the Okamoto clan and the Ejiri clan.
sen.cmt: Okamoto and Ejiri→the Okamoto clan and the Ejiri clanとしました。

sen.j: 他に、第一皇子克明親王の子に管弦の名手として有名な源博雅がいる。
sen.e: One of the descendants of the first prince Yoshiakira includes MINAMOTO no Hiromasa who was a real hand at orchestra.
One of the descendants of the first prince Yoshiakira includes MINAMOTO no Hiromasa who was a real hand at orchestra.
sen.cmt: Robert: "who was a real hand at orchestra." doesn’t make sense
sen.e: One of the descendants of the first prince Yoshiakira includes MINAMOTO no Hiromasa who was an expert in kangen (gagaku piece without dance).
sen.cmt: who was a real hand at orchestra→who was an expert in kangen (gagaku piece without dance) としました。

sen.j: 62代村上天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the sixty-second Emperor Murakami.
Descendants of the sixty-second Emperor Murakami.
Descendants of the sixty-second Emperor Murakami.

sen.j: 第七皇子の具平親王の子で藤原頼通の猶子となった右大臣源師房の子孫が栄えた。
sen.e: The descendants of the Udaijin MINAMOTO no Morofusa, who was a child of the seventh Prince Guhei and became a contractual adopted child of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, were prosperous.
The descendants of the Udaijin MINAMOTO no Morofusa, who was a child of the seventh Prince Guhei and became a contractual adopted child of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, were prosperous.
The descendants of the Udaijin MINAMOTO no Morofusa, who was a child of the seventh Prince Tomohira and became a contractual adopted child of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, were prosperous.

sen.j: その子孫からは多数の堂上家を輩出し、室町時代に足利氏に奪われるまで源氏長者は師房一族が独占した。
sen.e: The descendants produced many members of the Tosho Family and the members of Morofusa monopolized the Genji choja before Asikaga came in power in the Muromachi period.
The descendants produced many members of the Tosho Family and the members of Morofusa monopolized the Genji choja before Asikaga came in power in the Muromachi period.
The descendants produced many members of the Tosho-ke and the members of Morofusa monopolized the Genji choja (head of the Minamoto clan) before Asikaga came in power in the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: 表記統一のため、Tosho Family→Tosho-keとし、Genji chojaの補足追加

sen.j: 63代冷泉天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the sixty-third Emperor Reizei.
Descendants of the sixty-third Emperor Reizei.
Descendants of the sixty-third Emperor Reizei.

sen.j: 二十一流に含まれるが具体的に源姓を賜与された子孫の名は伝わらない。
sen.e: They belonged to one of the Nijyu-ichi ryu (the twenty-one lineages of the Genji clan) who was given the surname of Minamoto but their own names did not come down to posterity.
They belonged to one of the Nijyu-ichi ryu (the twenty-one lineages of the Genji clan) who was given the surname of Minamoto but their own names were not passed on.
They belonged to one of the Niju-ichi ryu (the twenty-one lineages of the Minamoto clan) who was given the surname of Minamoto but their own names were not passed on.
sen.cmt: Nijyu-ichi→Niju-ichi、the Genji clan→the Minamoto clanに修正

sen.j: 65代花山天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the sixty-fifth Emperor Kazan.
Descendants of the sixty-fifth Emperor Kazan.
Descendants of the sixty-fifth Emperor Kazan.

sen.j: 堂上家の白川伯王家となり、神祇官を世襲して神道を統括した。
sen.e: They constituted the Shirakawa Hakuo family and controlled the Shintoism by holding the Department of Worship from generation to generation.
They constituted the Shirakawa Hakuo family and controlled the Shintoism by holding the Department of Worship from generation to generation.
They constituted the Shirakawa Hakuo family of the Tosho-ke and controlled the Shintoism by holding the Department of Worship from generation to generation.

sen.j: 67代三条天皇の第一皇子敦明親王の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the first Prince Atsuakira of the sixty-seventh Emperor Sanjo.
Descendants of the first Prince Atsuakira of the sixty-seventh Emperor Sanjo.
Descendants of the first Prince Atsuakira of the sixty-seventh Emperor Sanjo.

sen.j: 嫡流は源通季以降正親司を世襲し、五位の王氏に復した。
sen.e: On and after MINAMOTO no Michisue, their direct line held the Okiminotsuka from generation to generation to come back in the Imperial family of fifth degree.
On and after MINAMOTO no Michisue, their direct line held the Okiminotsuka from generation to generation to finally come back five degrees from the Imperial family.
On and after MINAMOTO no Michisue, their direct line held the Okimi no Tsukasa (Royal Family Office) from generation to generation to finally come back five degrees from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: Okiminotsuka→Okimi no Tsukasaとし、補足追加 (参照: http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=BSmMbQhafJoC&pg=PA452&dq=Okimi-no-tsukasa&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=Okimi-no-tsukasa&f=false)

sen.j: 71代後三条天皇の第三皇子輔仁親王の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the third prince Sukehito of the 71st Emperor Gosanjo.
Descendants of the third prince Sukehito of the 71st Emperor Gosanjo.
Descendants of the third Prince Sukehito of the 71st Emperor Gosanjo.
sen.cmt: princeの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 輔仁親王の子源有仁は左大臣となった。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Arihito, a child of the Prince Sukehito, became Sadaijin.
MINAMOTO no Arihito, a child of the Prince Sukehito, became Sadaijin.
MINAMOTO no Arihito, a child of the Imperial Prince Sukehito, became Sadaijin.

sen.j: 源頼朝の家臣で平家物語にも登場する田代信綱は源有仁の孫とされる（『源平盛衰記』）。
sen.e: It is said that Nobutsuna TASHIRO, one of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo's retainers who appeared in the Heike Monogatari, was a grandchild of MINAMOTO no Arihito (see "Genpei Seisuiki").
It is said that Nobutsuna TASHIRO, one of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo's retainers who appeared in the Heike Monogatari, was a grandchild of MINAMOTO no Arihito (see "Genpei Seisuiki").
It is said that Nobutsuna TASHIRO, one of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo's retainers who appeared in the Heike Monogatari, was a grandchild of MINAMOTO no Arihito (see "Genpei Seisuiki").

sen.j: 77代後白河天皇の第二皇子・以仁王（高倉宮）。
sen.e: The second Prince Mochihito (Takakura) of the seventy-seventh Emperor Goshirakawa.
The second Prince Mochihito (Takakura) of the seventy-seventh Emperor Goshirakawa.
The second Prince Mochihito (Takakura) of the seventy-seventh Emperor Goshirakawa.

sen.j: 以仁王は親王宣下がなされず、ついに治承4年（1180年）、最勝親王を名乗り安徳天皇と平氏政権の排除を唱えて源頼政とともに挙兵するが、敗死した（以仁王の挙兵）。
sen.e: The Prince Mochihito, who was not entitled to hold the name of Imperial prince, named himself the Prince Saikatsu in 1180 and raised an army with MINAMOTO no Yorimasa under the slogan of eliminating the Emperor Antoku and the Heishi Seiken (the government of the Taira clan) but was killed in a battle (Army raise of the Prince Mochihito).

The Prince Mochihito, who was not entitled to hold the name of Imperial prince, named himself the Prince Saikatsu in 1180 and raised an army with MINAMOTO no Yorimasa under the slogan of eliminating the Emperor Antoku and the Heishi Seiken (the government of the Taira clan) but was killed in a battle (army raised by Prince Mochihito).

The Prince Mochihito, who was not entitled to hold the name of Imperial prince, named himself the Imperial Prince Saisho in 1180 and raised an army with MINAMOTO no Yorimasa under the slogan of eliminating the Emperor Antoku and the Taira clan government but was killed in a battle (army raised by Prince Mochihito).
sen.cmt: Prince Saikatsu→Imperial Prince Saisho、the Heishi Seiken (the government of the Taira clan)→the Taira clan governmentとしました。

sen.j: その際、後白河院から源姓を賜与されて名も「以仁王」と改められ、流罪が下された。
sen.e: During this battle, he was given the surname of Minamoto by the Emperor Goshirakawa, was renamed the Prince Mochihito and was doomed into exile.
During this battle, he was given the surname of Minamoto by the Emperor Goshirakawa, was renamed the Prince Mochihito and was doomed into exile.
During this battle, he was given the surname of Minamoto by the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa, was renamed the Prince Mochihito and was doomed into exile.
sen.cmt: the Emperor Goshirakawa→the Retired Emperor Goshirakawaとしました。

sen.j: 84代順徳天皇の第五皇子・忠成王、第六皇子・善統親王の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the fifth Prince Tadanari and the sixth Prince Yoshimune of the eighty-fourth Emperor Juntoku.
Descendants of the fifth Prince Tadanari and the sixth Prince Yoshimune of the eighty-fourth Emperor Juntoku.
Descendants of the fifth Prince Tadanari and the sixth Prince Yoshimune of the eighty-fourth Emperor Juntoku.

sen.j: 善統親王の孫源善成は四辻を号し足利義満の応援も受けて左大臣に昇った。
sen.e: Minamoto no Yoshinari, a grandchild of the prince Yoshimune, called himself Yotsutuji and was promoted up to Sadaijin thanks to Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA's backup.
Minamoto no Yoshinari, a grandchild of the prince Yoshimune, called himself Yotsutuji and was promoted up to Sadaijin thanks to Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA's backup.
MINAMOTO no Yoshinari, a grandchild of the Imperial Prince Yoshimune, called himself Yotsutuji and was promoted up to Sadaijin thanks to Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA's backup.
sen.cmt: Minamoto no Yoshinari→MINAMOTO no Yoshinari、prince Yoshimune→Imperial Prince Yoshimuneに修正

sen.j: 88代後嵯峨天皇の孫・惟康親王。
sen.e: The Prince Koreyasu, a grandchild of the eighty-eighth Emperor Gosaga
The Prince Koreyasu, a grandchild of the eighty-eighth Emperor Gosaga
The Imperial Prince Koreyasu, a grandchild of the eighty-eighth Emperor Gosaga.
sen.cmt: Imperial Prince Koreyasuとし、ピリオド追加

sen.j: 後嵯峨天皇の第二皇子宗尊親王が第6代鎌倉将軍一覧を退いた後、その一男で7代将軍に就任した惟康親王に対し、源姓が賜与されて「源惟康」となった。
sen.e: After the Prince Munetaka, the second son of the Emperor Gosaga, retired from the list of the sixth Kamakura Shogun, Koreyasu, the eldest son, the Prince Munetaka, became the seventh Shogun and was given the surname of Minamoto, to call himself MINAMOTO no Koreyasu.

After the Prince Munetaka, the second son of the Emperor Gosaga, retired from the list of the sixth Kamakura Shogun, Koreyasu, the eldest son, the Prince Munetaka, became the seventh Shogun and was given the surname of Minamoto, to call himself MINAMOTO no Koreyasu.

After the Imperial Prince Munetaka, the second son of the Emperor Gosaga, retired from the list of the sixth Kamakura Shogun, Imperial Prince Koreyasu, the eldest son of the Imperial Prince Munetaka, became the seventh Shogun and was given the surname of Minamoto, to call himself MINAMOTO no Koreyasu.
sen.cmt: Prince Munetaka→Imperial Prince Munetaka、Koreyasu→Imperial Prince Koreyasuとし、the eldest son, the Prince Munetaka→the eldest son of the Imperial Prince Munetakaに修正

sen.j: ただし、その後鎌倉幕府が惟康を京へ追放し、代わりに久明親王を将軍に迎えるため、その下準備として幕府の要請により朝廷より惟康に対して親王宣下がなされ、惟康は皇族に復帰。
sen.e: After that, the Kamakura shognate expelled Koreyaku to Kyoto, then the Imerial court, at the request of the shogunate, gave him the title of prince as groudwork for receiving the Prince Hisaakira as shogun and Koreyasu

After that, the Kamakura shognate expelled Koreyaku to Kyoto, then the Imerial court, at the request of the shogunate, gave him the title of prince as groudwork for receiving the Prince Hisaakira as shogun and Koreyasu

After that, the Kamakura bakufu expelled Koreyaku to Kyoto, then the Imerial court, at the request of the bakufu, gave him the title of Imperial Prince as groudwork for receiving the Imperial Prince Hisaakira as shogun and Koreyasu returned to the Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: 「惟康は皇族に復帰」を訳出、the Kamakura shognate→the Kamakura bakufu、the shogunate→the bakufu、the title of prince→the title of Imperial Prince、Prince Hisaakira→Imperial Prince Hisaakiraに修正

sen.j: すなわち「後嵯峨源氏」は惟康一代で終わった。
sen.e: In other words, the Gosaga Genji ended in the lifetime of Koreyasu.
In other words, the Gosaga Genji ended during the lifetime of Koreyasu.
In other words, the Gosaga-Genji ended during the lifetime of Koreyasu.

sen.j: 89代後深草天皇の皇子で、鎌倉幕府8代征夷大将軍となった久明親王の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the Prince Hisaakira who was a son of the eighty-eighth Emperor Gofukakusa and who became the eighth Seiitaishogun of the Kamakura shognate.
Descendants of the Prince Hisaakira who was a son of the eighty-eighth Emperor Gofukakusa and who became the eighth Seiitaishogun of the Kamakura shognate.
Descendants of the Imperial Prince Hisaakira who was a son of the eighty-eighth Emperor Gofukakusa and who became the eighth Seii Taishogun of the Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: Imperial Prince Hisaakira、Seii Taishogun、 Kamakura bakufuとしました。

sen.j: 久明親王の子守邦親王（9代将軍）・久良親王が源姓を賜与されたとされる。
sen.e: It is said that the Prince Morikuni (ninth Shogun) and the Prince Hisanaga, both being children of the Prince Hisaakira, were given the surname of Minamoto.
It is said that the Prince Morikuni (ninth Shogun) and the Prince Hisanaga, both being children of the Prince Hisaakira, were given the surname of Minamoto.
It is said that Imperial Prince Morikuni (ninth Shogun) and Imperial Prince Hisanaga, both being children of the Imperial Prince Hisaakira, were given the surname of Minamoto.
sen.cmt: 一部the削除、Imperial Prince Morikuni、Imperial Prince Hisanaga、Imperial Prince Hisaakiraとしました。

sen.j: また、久良親王の猶子（実は二条道平の子）源宗明は大納言に昇った。
sen.e: In addition, MINAMOTO no Muneaki, adopted child by contract (in fact, child of Michihira NIJO), was promoted to Dainagon.
In addition, MINAMOTO no Muneaki, adopted a child by contract (in fact, a child of Michihira NIJO), and was promoted to Dainagon.
In addition, MINAMOTO no Muneaki, who was an adopted child of the Imperial Prince Hisanaga (in fact, a child of Michihira NIJO), was promoted to Dainagon (chief councilor of state).
sen.cmt: Dainagonの補足追加、原文の内容に沿わない部分を訳し直しました。

sen.j: 106代正親町天皇の子孫。
sen.e: Descendants of the hundred and sixth Emperor Ogimachi.
Descendants of the hundred and sixth Emperor Ogimachi.
Descendants of the hundred and sixth Emperor Ogimachi.

sen.j: 当初は武家だったが後に堂上家となり、広幡家（清華家）を興した。
sen.e: They formed at first a family of warriors and then became theTosho family and established the Hirohata family (the Seiga family).
They formed at first a family of warriors and then became theTosho family and established the Hirohata family (the Seiga family).
They formed at first a family of warriors and then became the Tosho-ke and established the Hirohata family (the Seiga family).
sen.cmt: 表記統一のため、theTosho family→the Tosho-keとしました。
